newsitem.title: INDIA: Bombay shares end down, foreign funds net sellers.
newsitem.headline: Bombay shares end down, foreign funds net sellers.

text.p: Share prices finished lower on Wednesday at the Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE) as an anticipated statement on tax proposals failed to emerge before trading ended, brokers said.
The 30-share BSE index fell 50.75 points, or 1.48 percent, to a provisional 3,384.08 at close.
The 50-stock National Stock Exchange (NSE) dropped 10.13 points, or 1.01 percent, to a provisional 990.87.
"The market was expecting some announcement but was disappointed," one trader said, referring to Finance Minister P. Chidambaram's expected statement on the budget proposals.
Chidambaram defended a controversial minimum alternate tax (MAT) in parliament after markets closed for the day.
"MAT is a justified levy. It will not be more than 12.9 percent," he said while introducing for voting the finance bill for fiscal 1996/97 (April-March).
Traders had been expecting the government to dilute the tax for some sectors like steel and cement.
"The market will seek lower levels if some incentives are not forthcoming," a trader said.
He said foreign and state-run domestic funds were net sellers during the day.
The 500-share CISIL index dropped 9.43 points, or 1.39 percent, to a provisional 668.97.
Reports that demand was slowing hit automobiles shares. TELCO fell 10.50 rupees to 465.25 and Bajaj Auto 28.75 to 986.25.
Selling by foreign funds dragged Gujarat Ambuja Cement down 12.50 to 287.50. ACC dropped 21.50 rupees to 2,025.
SBI shed 7.75 rupees to 268.75 on foreign selling. BSES lost 9.0 rupees to 187, ITC 7.25 to 288.50, Reliance 4.75 to 202.25, TISCO 3.50 to 183.75 and L&T 3.0 to 245.
